This Executive Summary briefly describes the following elements:

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source.
The stationary source and regulated substances handled.
The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario.
The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
The five-year accident history.
The emergency response program.
Planned changes to improve safety.

1. The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source

To address concerns of an accidental release, prevention and emergency response, all plant and field personnel are trained in ammonia emergency response procedures and use of appropriate protective equipment. Refresher training and emergency response drills are conducted on a periodic basis to ensure personnel are equipped, trained, prepared, and practiced in responding to ammonia emergencies. 

As a result of information gathered during preparation of this Risk Management Program, the Norpel facility is committing additional resources to further increase employee awareness and equipment reliability and to establish operator training and preventive maintenance programs. As a demonstration of the Norpel's high degree of commitment to public safety and service, the Norpel facility is taking action to decrease the risk of ammonia exposure to the public by implementing recommendations made during the Process Hazards Analysis and Off-site Consequence Analysis.

2. The stationary source and regulated substances handled

Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the Norpel refrigeration system. The liquid is circulated as needed to the evaporators where heat is absorbed and removed from the medium. The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is a closed loop two stage industrial re

frigeration system. The ammonia is not used or mixed in any manner with other chemical processes.

3. The "Worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario

A "Worst-Case Scenario Offsite Consequence Analysis" and an "Alternative Scenario Offsite Consequence Analysis" were performed identifying the public and environmental receptors within the toxic endpoint concentration radius of 200 ppm. The results are mitigated by the fact that all the vessels and the much of the piping are inside the Norpel building. A variety of administrative controls and computerized controls are in place to shut the system down when operating parameters and limits are exceeded.

4. The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific preventative steps

The basic elements of the Program 3 Prevention program have been developed and are in place. These include:

Process Safety Information
Process Hazard Analysis
Standard Operating Procedures
Safe Work Practices
Employee and Operator Training Programs
Mechanical Integrity Program
Management of Change Procedures
PSM/RMP Compliance Audit Procedures
Incident Investigation Procedures
Pre Start-up Safety Review Procedures
Employee Participation Program
Hot Work Permit Procedures
Contractor Safety Program
Emergency Response Program

Ammonia specific prevention steps include:

Administrative controls
Operator Training
Computerized controls

The Preventive Program 3 provides extensive maintenance and operator/mechanic training to ensure that the system's mechanical integrity is maintained for the life of the covered process. Program 3 also incorporates administrative controls when modifications are made to the covered process (ammonia refrigeration system), so the training and preventative programs are updated as the system expands and changes.

5. The five-year accident

history

There have been no incidents or accidents at the facility that meet the threshold for reporting for to the EPA in the past five (5) years. To prevent and/or minimize any potential future release of anhydrous ammonia, the Norpel is implementing a detailed Process Safety Management program (Preventive Program 3).

6. The emergency response program

Emergency response is discussed in the Risk Management Program (RMP) binder of the complete program. Norpel has a detailed Emergency Response Plan for their facility. The purpose of this plan is to provide the means for rapidly determining the appropriate response for any emergency that may develop at the facility such as an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  The Norpel facility will conduct scheduled drills of the emergency response plan. The Emergency Response Program is written, includes specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release, includes procedures for informing the public and local agencies responsible for responding to an accidental release, and includes information on emergency health care.

7. Planned changes to Improve safety.

Process Hazard Analysis recommendations will be addressed by internal resources as well as third party consulting. An Emergency Pressure Control System has been installed to prevent potential ammonia releases due to increased system pressures.
